HENRY HAPGOOD, a young friend of Goldie's.--------------Donald Bryen
WHITNEY WILSON, who also makes the trip-----------------Tim Lewis

list.item: ACT 1st -- Exterior Cecil Hotel - London, England.
ACT 2nd -- South Hampton Dock, St. Hurrah Steaming

div.head: -ACT 1.-
div.stage: (Opening number done by starter and all the chorus.)
(At opening of number reformers enter from 1st entrance left, and enter hotel, and appear on balcony.)
(During number the newsboy comes from 1.E.L. deals out papers to members of chorus, while he and starter are singing, starter following him around.)
(At finish of number, cabbies down stage - exit 1.E.L. and chorus stays up stage - pantomine talk.)

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Here, here, keep to the left - keep to the left.
Drives his cab to the right like a blooming Yankee.
sp.stage: (Enter Henry from hotel and down to starter)

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Good morning, starter.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: A ripping nice morning, yes sir.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Fine day for the derby.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Yes indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.stage: (Henry turns to L. and looks up at decorations.)
sp.p: Tell me, what are these decorations for.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Decorations, haven't you heard? Sing Song, the great Chinese newspaper man here to see the Derby. They do say the Emperor sent him. Four of the Emperor's wards are with him, sir.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Emperor's wards!

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Sure. Chinese women my word, they are a sight.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Are there many Americans here?

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: All sorts and sizes, sir.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Notice any uncommon, extraordinary, I might say suspicious ones among them?

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Say, where are you from? Scotland Yards?

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: You talk like a blooming inspector. Something up, is there?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Why no, -- but --

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Something you want to know, sir?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: There you are again - well here.
Is there a Mrs. Kenworth here?

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Mrs. Kenworth, oh, yes, sir. She's been here for several days, sir.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Who's with her?

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: A lot of young females, sir. Some sort of a reforming society, I understand. They look like Salvation Army folks to me, sir.

div.stage: (At this girls enter from hotel. Come down stage, all turn and look up at balcony, and discover reformers. Pointing up and laughing, both Henry and Starter turn, and both look up at balcony and cross to extreme left.)

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: There they are, sir. Them is them, sir.
sp.stage: (At this girl comes down stage C. surrounded by all the girls and Starter stays extreme L. looking off. Henry goes up stage, talks to boys.)

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Do you know who they are?

sp.speaker: All the Girls.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: They're the San Francisco Female Reformers.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: They tried to close up the Chinese Lottery game.
sp.stage: (Girls all laugh-turn and go up stage. 1st girl goes up to extreme R. and Henry comes down to Starter.)

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Much obliged to you Starter for the information.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Anything else I can do, sir?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, stop holding out your hand all the time.
sp.stage: (Laughs, runs up to hotel and exits.)

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Thank you sir.
Here, here- drive to the left - drive to the left.
sp.stage: (In the meantime, boy comes from door R. down to first girl with papers - she takes one, reads and goes to C.)

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Look here, girls, it says Yankee Doodle is the favorite in the Derby.

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl.
sp.p: Who rides Him?

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: It doesn't say.
sp.stage: (Enter McGee from hotel and right down to girls.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: That's all right now, etc.-----

sp.speaker: Girls.
sp.p: It's Mr. McGee.
sp.stage: (All run up to him and crowd around him)
(Business here of him trying to back away, and finally succeeds.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: By gorra's I wish you girls wouldn't be so glad to see me, but say, I got great news for you, but remember it's a secret.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A secret?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I can see this bunch keeping a secret. Listen to this. "Go as far as you like on the English Derby". J. J.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Who's J. J.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Johnny Jones, the American jockey.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: What's he ride?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yankee Doodle, and any time Jones says bet, the race is in. He left Paris last night - he'll be here before noon.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Will you introduce us to Mr. Jones?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Don't be afraid, he'll introduce himself. Now remember I've chartered a tally-ho for the Derby and we'll all go together.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.stage: (To first girl with arm around her)
sp.p: But don't mention the tip. Mum's the word.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Mum's the word.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And if they run out of Mums, we'll drink any old thing they've got.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. McGee I think you're the dearest, darlingest and sweetest man that ever - - -
sp.stage: (Bus. of taking roll of greenbacks from his pockets.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Rough work - rough work.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: What's this, American Money?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yes, American money.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: It's no good over here.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.stage: (Taking it and putting it in pocket on other side.)
sp.p: No, then I'll put it over here.
sp.stage: (At this, 1st girl releases him and runs off - sore. Exits 1st entrance R.)
sp.p: But all joking aside
sp.stage: (Turns and girls all come down and surround him.)
sp.p: I'd like to meet you girls in New York.

sp.speaker: All girls.
sp.p: Oh, New York.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I may not be the whole thing in England, but in New York, why say-- they're all my friends.
sp.stage: (MUSIC CUE - SONG - "THEY'RE ALL MY FRIENDS" - done by McGee and Chrous. - at finish of number the girls all exit either side and music continues and McGee and boys continues singing and dancing. At finish boys exit. 1st E. L. and Reformers exit balcony. McGee sits at right of table at extreme left. Boy enters from door R. whistling. McGee turns and calls him.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Say, Boy, is there any mail?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What's the name, sir?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Timothy D. McGee.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I'll see, sir.
sp.stage: (Enter Fly from hotel - comes down to table where McGee is.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Timothy D. McGee -- in London, quite a bit of news for the society columns I must say.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I'm all out of wind, a man of any age shouldn't be dancing.
Florabelle Fly!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: As ever yours, Florabelle.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: What brought you here?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: The American line, of course.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Here to do the Derby, eh?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Exactly, and incidentally making notes of the different celebrities, I come in contact with.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Still in the newspaper business, eh?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Still scribbling scribbles for the San Francisco Searcher. Tell me, what are you doing here, Mack?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Come to see the Derby.

sp.speaker: Fly. Is that all?
sp.p: McGee. And why?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Oh, nothing, I see Anthony Anstey is here.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Anthony Anstey.

sp.speaker:
Fly. Yes.
McGee.
sp.p: In London?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: What's he here for?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Why do you ask?

sp.speaker: McGee
sp.p: Oh, nothing, but - - -

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: But you have an idea he's here after Johnny Jones, isn't that is, Mack?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: No, not exactly - - -

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: And you are here for the same purpose.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And who told you?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Common Sense. If I meet a lady in Paris, I know she's there for hats and gowns. If I meet a horse owner in London, I know he's here for Johnny Jones. Have you seen him yet?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Well, to tell you the truth, I have not.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Don't be afraid Mack. I'll not print your secret. Where is Jones?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: He's on his way from Paris.
sp.stage: (At this Fly gets up - crosses in front of table and stools to C.)
sp.p: Gets here about noon, I guess. But tell me, Fly, are you sure Anstey's after him.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Do you know a horse owner who isn't?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I guess you're right.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: You see Anstey's in a trifling way connected with the story I'm after, for the Searcher, and oh, such a story, Mack.
sp.stage: (At this she strolls to McGee's side)
sp.p: Inside of a few days I expect to have a page or two of sensational reading that will throw our 'Frisco competitors into seven kinds of journalistic fits.
sp.stage: (Then she turns and strolls to extreme right.)

sp.speaker:
McGee. Murder?
Fly.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: McGee. Robbery?
sp.p: Fly. No.

sp.speaker: McGee Love affair.
sp.p: Fly. There you have it.
sp.stage: (McGee gets up and goes over to Fly. Laughs.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Story about a girl going to marry an English Lord.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No, a story about a girl who doesn't want to marry an English Lord.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: That ought to make a good story.
sp.stage: (Enter servant - 2nd entrance L. with note on tray and hands same to McGee.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Boy. Mr. McGee?
sp.p: McGee.
What's this?
Sing Song wants to see me.
sp.stage: (Bus. Boy. bows affirmatively, and goes to 2nd E.L. and stays there.)

sp.speaker: Fly. Sing Song?
sp.p: McGee. Yes, the Chinese newspaper man. Here to do the Derby. Haven't you met him?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I'd like to.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Come on, I'll introduce you.
sp.stage: (Turns to go at same time to servant.)
sp.p: Tell him I'll be right there.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Chinese newspaper man - whoever heard of such a thing?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yes, the Editor of the Pekin Gazette, and a real live sport.

sp.speaker: Fly. (Laughs)
sp.p: Chinaman, - Sport?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Sent here by the Emporer.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: The Emperor?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: So they say, but come on, I want you to meet him.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: This will make a story in itself. Chinese newspaper man - funniest thing I ever heard.
sp.stage: (Enter Henry from Hotel. Looks about. Enter boy from door L. Shouting "Johnny Jones". Crosses and exits in door R.)

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.stage: (When boy exits, Henry comes down stage and calls.)
sp.p: All right Goldie, come right along, the coast is clear.
sp.stage: (Music double Forte, and enter Goldie Gates from hotel, over to table R.) (Henry follows)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Are you quite sure?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Not a soul in sight.
sp.stage: (Fly enters from door L. goes to C. and discovers them.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: What a relief. I've never been so nervous in all my life.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Pluck up courage- everything is going along nicely. I've a thousand things to tell you.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Do you suppose any one suspects?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, but be careful. Don't get into conversation with any one. I've given them to understand here that you're a French girl, and no one knows a thing about you.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Except Florabelle Fly. What a story - what a scoop for the Searcher.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Tell me, what have you heard?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: A thousand things, Goldie. To begin with, your aunt has engaged herself to be married.

sp.speaker: Goldie. To whom?
sp.p: Henry Anthony Anstey, an American gambler.
sp.stage: (At this Goldie sits at R. of table)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: A gambler? Anthony Anstey? He comes from 'Frisco and is well known.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Notoriously so. That man would rob a newsboy of a Canadian dime.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Aunt Annette engaged to be married.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Now don't get meritorious.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: But what of this husband she's picked out for me - this nobleman?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Lord Walter Wetherington-Earl of Bloomsbury.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: The Earl of Bloomsbury!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, a young man who desires to tie up with an American heiress. Anstey is to introduce him to your Aunt.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Oh, then she hasn't met him yet?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, I understand he is to be here today.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Good, then I'll get a look at my future husband.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Look here, Goldie, there is some sort of a game on foot between this man Anstey and this Chinese newspaper man, Sing Song.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: What makes you think so?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Closeted meetings. Whispered conversations - all sorts of mysterious notions.
sp.stage: (Henry goes up to the L. side of table. Faces Goldie.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: What sort of a looking man is this Anstey?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Well, he's a man of about fifty, rather short, keen-eyed and-

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Going to the Derby? Well, I should say I am going to the Derby.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Here he is now.
sp.stage: (Henry goes L. Enter Anstey from hotel- comes down stage C.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Glorious land of the - - - - -

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Anstey, good morning, sir!

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Ah, good morning. Why as I live, the young man I met at the American bar last evening.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: The same sir. Identically the same.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Fine day for the Derby.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Glorious.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Who's your friend?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, beg pardon, allow me.
Mlle., I present Monsieur Anstey, Rosario Fanchonette -
sp.stage: (Goldie gets up and Henry crosses to L.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Delighted Monsieur. Oh, you have such beautiful hair.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Let's all have a drink.
Waiter.
sp.stage: (Waiter who has been up stage comes down.)
sp.p: A quart of wine - you know the vintage I mean.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Aye, Governor.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You are going to the Derby, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Oui, oui, that is why I come from Paris.
sp.stage: (Goldie goes in back of right chair.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Oh, you come from Paree.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, she's a French girl.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: A French girl, well, well! A French girl from Paree. That's strange.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That is rather strange.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: You are an American gentleman? Yes?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: American, all wool and a yard wide.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: What makes the Americans so proud of their country?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Other countries.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Henry.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Very good, very good!

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You like the Americans, eh?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Not so much. The English are much better.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, you see, Mlle. prefers titled gentlemen. She has a score of acquaintances amongst the nobilities.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Run away, young man, run away.
sp.stage: (At this Henry turns and goes L.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Nobility! Do you know the Earl of Bloomsbury?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Ah! He is my dear friend.
sp.stage: (Anstey interested. Henry up stage, watches what is going on.)
sp.p: He will be here today.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: No, the Earl will not be here for a week.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Will not be here for a week.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: No, not for a week.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Tell me, who is this heiress?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Only a school girl.
sp.stage: (At this Goldie crosses in back of table to C. and motions Henry to go.)
(Henry goes up steps of hotel and stays there.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Only a school girl?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, a beautiful young school girl.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: She is very beautiful?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.stage: (At this Anstey gets up and goes over to Goldie.)
sp.p: Well, I've never seen her myself, but - - -

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Ah, you're engaged to be married.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Now, who told you?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Oh, I heard, Madam Kenworth has lots of money.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, she has lots of money.

sp.speaker: Goldie
sp.p: Ah, you are a wise old guy, all right, all right.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: A wise old guy?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: You are a flirt Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: A flirt, in London, why not? Paris is a gay town.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: You've never been in Paree?

sp.speaker: Anstey. Never.
sp.p: Goldie
Oh, Monsieur!
sp.stage: (MUSIC CUE) SONG -"MLLE. FANCHETTE" (Bus. of Henry and Anstey during song.)
(Henry exits R. At finish of number, exits Goldie door L.)
(Over to table R. and laughs heartily. Sits down. Waiter enters with wine in cooler from hotel down to Anstey.)

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Here's your wine, sir.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I ordered that wine a half hour ago.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.stage: (Bus. Enters from hotel also. Down to Amstey.)
sp.p: You didn't say as how you were in a hurry, sir.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Americans are always in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: So it seems, sir.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I don't want the wine now.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Very good, sir.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: You know America is not the only country in the world, sir?

sp.speaker: Anstey. Isn't it?
sp.p: Starter. No sir. England's on the map, sir.

sp.speaker: Anstey. Is it?
sp.p: Starter. Yes, sir. Anything else, sir?

sp.speaker: Anstey. No sir.
sp.p: Starter. Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Damn fool.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Idiot!

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Anglo Saxon Brotherhood.
sp.stage: (Enter Fly and McGee from door L. Down stage C. Fly at R. of McGee. Both laughing.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Chinese newspaper man. It's an awful joke with me.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yes, and me too.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: You say you are going to have a tally-ho to the Derby?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yes, won't you join us?
sp.stage: (Anstey turns-discovers Fly and gets up, surprised.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: With pleasure.
why, Mr. Anstey.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Hello, Anstey!

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Tim McGee.
Well, well, this is a surprise.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: What are you doing over here?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Well, I was always crazy to come to London.
sp.stage: (McGee and Anstey stroll to table L. McGee sits at L. Anstey at R. Fly strolls over behind table L.C.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I think anybody's crazy to come to London.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Here to see the Derby?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, that is I - - - - -

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I see Johnny Jones rides in the Derby.
sp.stage: (McGee and Anstey both turn and look at each other, and then turn away)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Just as I suspected.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: He's after the kid sure enough.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I'll keep my weather eye on you, Mr. Anstey.
Bye, bye gentlemen.
I must dig up some more celebrities for my article on Americans abroad. News is not hard to find around the Cecil hotel.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: How's 'Frisco?

sp.speaker: Anstey. Slam Bang.
sp.p: McGee. How is the stable?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Not so loud, Mack.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: What's the matter, ruled off?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Hardly. But it isn't necessary that every one should know that I'm a race track man. Why not a retired merchant or something of that sort?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And what's the idea?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Women at the bottom of it.

sp.speaker: McGee
sp.p: Women, and who is your friend?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: More than my friend, my fiancee.

sp.speaker: McGee. Engaged?
sp.p: Anstey. Surest thing you know. Came all the way from 'Frisco together - got so we could coo in a business-like manner. By the time we hit London, we were engaged to be married.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Wonderfully romantic. I suppose you told her everything you know.
sp.stage: (Bus. Anstey gets up strolls to C. and turns.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: She's heard my life story from the cradle to the grave.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Did you tell her your right name?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: She knows my name, but not my game.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: She doesn't suspect that you're mixed up with the ponies.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Ponies - why certainly not. You must know, my dear boy, she is the President of an organization known as the San Francisco Female Reformers, a band of young Western damsels that would make any Parkhurst Society blush with shame. Why their attack upon 'Frisco's Chinatown cleaned out the pigtail quarters,
sp.stage: (Bus. Anstey strolls to C. and then strolls back behind table to such an extent that the Highbinders have already threatened the life of the future Mrs. Anstey.
(At this boy enters from hotel shouting.)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Telegram for Johnny Jones.
sp.stage: (Continues shouting and exits door R. At same time American boy and girl enter from E.R. and exit into hotel. Anstey by this time is behind table and McGee gets up. Both look toward boy; after boy exits McGee sits down and Anstey still looks toward boy.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: The Highbinders threatened her life?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Eh!
Papers still full of it all over the Pacific Coast.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: What brought her to London?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Here to find a suitable husband for her niece. An Earl, a Duke, or something of that sort.

sp.speaker: McGee. Her Niece?
sp.p: Anstey. Yes, daughter of the late Gerald Gates.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Gerald Gates, the millionaire?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: My fiancee is his widowed sister, Mrs. Kensworth.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Mrs. Andrew Kenworth - one of the richest women in the West?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Misjudge me not, man, I am not marrying her because she has twenty millions.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: Anstey
sp.p: I'd marry her if she had forty millions.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Spoken like a true American, and she's here to buy a title?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: That is if all the titles in England are not copyrighted.
sp.stage: (Music, soft waltz at this point and Reformers enter from hotel)
(A lot of talk and stay up stage.)
(Anstey and McGee get up, turn and see them.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Look, them are those, I mean those are them, these are they.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Anstey
sp.p: Members of my fiancee's society.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Did she bring them with her?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: They are with her all the time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Where are you, my chidren?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Here she is now.
sp.stage: (Enter Mrs. Kenworth from hotel and down stage C.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Anthony.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: My dear Annette.
I present an old time friend, Mr. McGee.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Timothy D. McGee. At your service.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: From the other side?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: East side, tenth ward.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: My children.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Your children?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Not my daughters, my children. We are organized for a purpose that is sweet and dear to us. We love each other, do we not, my dearies?

sp.speaker: Six. Yes, Mamma.
sp.p: Mrs. Kenworth. I suppose Anthony has told you of our engagment?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: He has, and allow me to congratulate you both, and permit me to say that ever before has it been my good fortune to meet so sweet and amiable a woman.
sp.stage: (Bus. McGee gets very close to Mrs. Kenworth at this.)
sp.p: Such beauty, such elegance and such - - - -

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Oh, Mack, just a minute.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Excuse me.
sp.stage: (Turns to him and talks in pantomine)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Now, children, remember London is a very large city, and you must be very careful where and how you get about. You should have an escort.
sp.stage: (Looks over at Anstey, then turns to Reformers again.)
sp.p: I have it.
Anthony.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, my dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: I want you to show the girls about town. Point out the different historial buildings and so on.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: All right, my dear.
sp.stage: (They cross. Mrs. Kenworth goes down to McGee, who is looking the other way.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: And now Mr. McGee if it is not too much
I will ask you to escort me as far as Picadilly. I have quite some shopping to do.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: The pleasure is mine Mrs. Kenworth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: You'll take good care of the little dearies, won't you, Anthony?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: The Best of care, my dear.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yes, be careful crossing the streets.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Now, you don't mind, do you?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Not at all, not at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: It's very very kind of you.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Stick around, don't go away.
sp.stage: (They exit arm in arm laughing and talking L.1.E.)
(Reformers go up stage. Anstey looks after McGee and Mrs. Kenworth, and then down stage C.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Laugh on my proud beauty. He who laughs screams with delight. You'll close up 'Frisco's China Lottery, will you? Cheat me out of one hundred thousand dollars a year, will you? Wait till you are Mrs. Anstey.
I'll soon teach you and your crusading band of fool women to stay at home and mind your own damn business. McGee wants Jones. He shan't have him.
I'll pay that Jockey more money than any man on the American turf.
sp.stage: (Reformers come down stage, extreme right at this and line up and call.)

sp.speaker: Six.
sp.p: We are waiting, kind sir.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Oh, Lord. Imagine me parading the streets of London with six puny looking, pale-faced females.
sp.stage: (Enter starter, blowing whistle. Over to girls.)

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: 'Ansom, ladies, 'ansom.
'ansom, sir, 'ansom.

sp.speaker: Six.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, six of them. Drive in a row like a circus parade. Take good care of the little dearies, and see that they are back here in an hour, and if anybody asks for me, tell them I am telling funny stories to Sing Song, the Chinese newspaper man.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Yes sir.
Beg pardon, ladies, one moment ladies.
Six 'ansoms, six 'ansoms.
sp.stage: (Enter cabbies and do the number with six Reformers. At finish of number, lot of laughing on inside. Enter Whitney Wilson from Hotel, with a bun on. Goes down to table left.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I have been down in the American bar, and I have an American cocktail that would choke a Hoboken cab driver. The bar tender got sore on me because I said I could lick Charley Mitchell.
sp.stage: (Hits bell on table. Waiter with tray and tea on same enters at this from door R. and down to Wilson.)

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Did you call me, sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: No, but I will if you give me any lip. I'll call you or anybody else. What time is it?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: 31st of May, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I know the date, what time is it?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Do you mean the hour, sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Can you beat that?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Half after eleven, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Half after eleven, sir.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Correct, sir. Do you feel like a cup of tea, sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: No, I don't feel like a cup of tea. Do I look like a cup of tea?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: I have a cup of tea here, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Well, go ahead and drink it, don't let me stop you.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Twenty-three.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Twenty-three.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Who, sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: You.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: No sir, thirty-six. Is there anything else I can do, sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: If there was you wouldn't be a waiter.
sp.stage: (Waiter turns and exits into door L.)
sp.p: Now he's what I call a nice little fellow. If I lived here we'd be together all the time.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.stage: (Enters at this from hotel down to Wilson)
sp.p: Morning, sir. Like to take a drive this morning?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Yes, drive me to a drink. Who are you?

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: I'm the starter, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: The Starter?

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Well, don't you start anything you can't finish.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Very good, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson
sp.p: What are you, a soldier?

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: No, sir. I'm not a soldier.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Well you ought to be ashamed of yourself. Why don't you be a soldier? Go to war and fight for your country.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: But there's no war now, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Then start one. What's the good of brass buttons if there ain't going to be a war?

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: I hope we'll never have another war, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Hope we'll never have another war. How do you suppose the soldiers are going to make a living if there ain't goin' to be any war?
Come on, let's get a drink.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: I don't drink, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Don't drink? How do you expect the saloons to keep open if you don't drink? Gee, whiz, you've got a mean disposition. You don't want any war, and you don't drink. If you keep on you'll put all the soldiers and saloons and keepers out of business.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Twenty-three.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: What, sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Twenty-three.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: I don't understand, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Certainly you don't. I'll bet you a ten pound note you don't know how much twenty-three is.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: I never gamble, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Never gamble. Now how do you expect to circulate currency? Gee, whiz, you just signed a peace treaty, and throw all the war correspondents out of work, Carrie Nations all the saloons and now you're going to close up all the gambling houses.
You've got the meanest disposition of any man I've met since I've been here, and I certainly had a good time here in Pittsburgh.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Pittsburgh?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I mean, London. Ain't it funny I always get these two towns mixed? London and Pittsburgh. But say, no joking, London is a great town for fun.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Right you are, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Never mind what these other Americans say, I've been a sport all my life.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: You look it, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: And you take it from me, for a good time London makes Worcaster and Springfield look like thirty cents.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Shall I call you a hansom sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Call me anything you like.
Sticks and stones will hurt my bones, but names will never break me.
sp.stage: (Enter Florabelle with girls from hotel- down stage C.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: You know I'm awfully glad to meet you girls, it's such a treat for Americans to meet Americans abroad. All going to the Derby, I suppose.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. McGee is going to take us.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Good, I'll be with you. We'll all put a bet on Yankee Doodle.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Johnny Jones rides Yankee Doodle.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes, do you know him?
It's a shame to bet on him. It's like taking candy away from a baby.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: He must be a bird.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Why girls he'll just coax that horse's nose by the wire like the Yankee bird coaxed the English sparrow to America.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.stage: MUSIC CUE. "NESTING IN A NEW YORK TREE". Sung by Fly and Girls. Fly and Girls exit at finish of number.
MUSIC CUE. Enter Anstey followed by Sing Song from door L. Down stage C.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: We can talk better in the open Sing.

sp.speaker: Sing Song.
sp.p: Tell me, Anstey, does this American jockey Jones ride in to-day's Derby?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Jones is on the favorite, Yankee Doodle.

sp.speaker: Sing Song.
sp.p: And you think Mr. McGee is here to get him.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: He's not the only one. Ever since Jones made the fact Public that he would return to America, hundreds of horse owners have made him fabulous offers. I've already sent him a check for ten thousand dollars for first call on his services.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Ahha, the early bird, Eh?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Nay, nay, the wise owl.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: But this band of Reformers, where are they?

sp.speaker: Anstey
sp.p: You'll see them soon enough, never fear.
sp.stage: (Both to table and sit down. Anstey right chair, Sing left chair.) (Wilson enters from door R. crosses to table L. and sits down.)

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Tell me, why did you make the meeting place London?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Because the Chinese Lottery game is not safe in America with Mrs. Kenworth there. I drove her from that country with threats supposedly made by the Highbinders, followed her here, forced my acquaintance upon her, now we are engaged to be married.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: She has money?

sp.speaker: Anstey
sp.p: All kinds, I'l get the money, never fear.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Anstey, you're a shrewd man.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: It's for your protection as well as my own. Haven't we been partners for five years?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: True, the Chinese Lottery in America has made a fortune for you and for me. But should the Emperor discover that I am connected with the game -
off would go my head.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: How did you manage to get here?
sp.stage: (Wilson gets up and strolls up to hotel and enters.)

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Easily enough. Since your last visit to China, I've been made editor of the Pekin Gazette. Upon receiving word from you to come to London, I suggested to His Majesty the idea of coming here and writing a story on the English Derby, so here I am. Now what are your plans?
sp.stage: (Anstey gets up and goes to C.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You must come with me to San Francisco.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Because the game is at a standstill. The Chinamen are afraid to operate. All I've said and done is of no avail. A word from you and the game goes on.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: But this woman and her band of - - - -

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Leave that to me - once my wife. I'll guarantee her band of Reformers will be no more.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Soft, Peddle. Here comes the words.
sp.stage: (Anstey goes to extreme left. Chinese girls enter from door left and down stage C. and sit on pillows.)

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Ahmila, Amoy, Agoy, Ahfung. Hung, Tun, Hila Muck a ting. Sung Fing Ko To la ma Fo Lung Ching tee.
I told them you were a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Those are the Emperor's four favorite wards. Wanted to see England and America, so he sent them in my charge.
sp.stage: (Laughter from inside by McGee and Mrs. Kenworth)

sp.speaker: Antsey.
sp.p: Here comes the fair lady now.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Mrs. Kenworth!

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, and Mr. McGee, the man that's after Jones.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: What about this nobleman?
sp.stage: (At this Anstey crosses and goes to extreme R. Sing follows.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I get 50% of his income.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Antsey you are a shrewd man.

sp.speaker: Antsey.
sp.p: I'm a business man.
sp.stage: (Both talking in pantomine. Enter McGee and Mrs. Kenworth L.1.E. laughing)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Now don't over laugh yourself.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: I don't know when I've enjoyed a stroll so much.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Here too, Mrs. Kenworth, and all me to say that never before - - - -

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth
sp.p: Look, look, save me, save me, Anthony.

sp.speaker: Antsey.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, my dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Anthony the Highbinders are after me.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Nonsense, my dear. I have the honor to present Sing Song, a Chinese newspaper man. This lady, Sing, is Mrs. Kenworth of whom I wrote you in my last letter.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.stage: (Crosses to Mrs. Kenworth. Anstey goes to C.)
sp.p: Ah, Charmed Mrs. Kenworth. Mr. Anstey has told me of the good work you are doing and believe me I am as much opposed to Chinese gambling as you are yourself, and if I can be of any service to you, pray commend me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: You are very kind, sir.
Take me away from here.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. McGee.

sp.speaker: McGee. Hello, Sing.
sp.p: Sing. I no see you a long time.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Going to the Derby, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: That's it. His Majesty has sent me here to write of the English and American sports. There are his four favorite wards.
Hung Tung, Hi la Muck a Wing. Sung Fing Ko To la ma Fo Lung, Ching tee. I told them who you were.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I thought you were singing a song.
sp.stage: (Enter Wilson from hotel, Sing goes extreme R. Laughing from inside.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: That's right, make a fool out of me. That's the way with you Englishmen, you're always kidding the poor Americans.
Hello, what's this? A Chinese comic opera?
How do do, ladies.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: How do you do, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson
sp.p: Just the fellow I want to see.
Say, if I give you some laundry to-night, can I get it Friday night?
sp.stage: (Sing gets very sore. A lot of Chinese talk. In his anger walks up and down, talking to Chinese girls.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Gee, he's got a mean disposition.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: He's no laundryman.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: What is he, a juggler, or a musician?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: He's the editor of a Chinese newspaper sent here by the Emperor.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Oh, I beg your pardon. I didn't know you were a press agent.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Press Agent! Press Agent!

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: How's everything in China?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: China's doing nicely.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: How's the emp----

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Who - what?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: The Emp--- the main squeeze.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: The main squeeze?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Yes, the big smoke.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Do you mean his royal Majesty, the Emperor?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.stage: (Sing goes to girls and talks Chinese.)

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Come, my little ones, it's time to chop suey.
sp.stage: (Sing and girls go up stage with music and off door left.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.stage: (Wilson and McGee go over to R. table and sit down.)
sp.p: They run like a lot of ducks.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: You're an American, aren't you?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I don't look like a Dago, do I?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Here to see the Derby.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: To tell you the truth, I don't know what I'm here for. I got on a boat in New York to bid a friend good-bye, and I fell asleep. When I awoke I was all at sea. My wife is waiting for me on the dock. That's ten days ago.
She's still waiting for me on the dock. Now I'M even.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And how is that?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: She used to keep me waiting for her out in front of Siegel & Cooper's. I remember one day she kept me waiting pretty near three days.
sp.stage: (McGee and Wilson talking and laughing quietly.)

(Enter American girl singing from 1.E.R. passes McGee and Wilson. Then turns to them smiling. Runs up into hotel, Wilson excuses himself to McGee and starts to follows her, but stops up stage. McGee gets up. Enter starter, with grip. L.1.E. followed by cabbie with another grip to C.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Here, here, come back here.
By golly that fellow takes the cake.
sp.stage: (Cabby enters with grip. Calls to Starter.)

sp.speaker: Cabby.
sp.p: Here's the other one, sir.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: I say, you know who your fare is?

sp.speaker: Cabby.
sp.p: Blowed if I do.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Johnny Jones.

sp.speaker: Cabby.
sp.p: Johnny Jones? My word, let's see him go by.
sp.stage: (Starter and cabby stand left, and Jones enters whistling, and walks by them to C.)
(Jones gives dog to servant who exits with dog to hotel.)

sp.speaker: Jones. Hello, Mack.
sp.p: McGee. Well, Jonsey, my boy.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Isn't he a ripper?

sp.speaker: Cabby.
sp.p: He's a pippin, sir.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Well, Jonsey, old boy, how are you?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Fine and dandy. Boston nobby. Fat and fine and splendid.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: How did you leave Paris?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Perfectly sober, the way you see me now.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Put your luggage in, sir?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Yes, put it right in, that's the boy.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Say, boy, will you join me in a drink?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: No, thanks, nothing doing.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: How about you?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Not for mine.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I must have company. A drink is no good without sociability. Sociability is no good without a drink.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: That's a good speech.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Yes, but it doesn't make me thirsty.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Well, I'll see you boys later. Make it as late as possible. I'm a late boy.
If you see anything of King Edmund trotting along here, tell him I'm satisfied with life.
sp.stage: (Jones and McGee watch him until off.)

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: He's a nice fellow.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Oh, he's all right.

sp.speaker: Jones. I like him.
sp.p: McGee
I can see that.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Who is he, Mack?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Nobody to know.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: What brought you to London?

sp.speaker:
McGee. You.
Jones.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: You're going back to America?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Yes, with bells on.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I want you, Jones.

sp.speaker: Jones. What for?
sp.p: McGee. Because you're the best jockey in the world. Name your price, I'll - - -

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Let's not talk shop, Mack. I've half way agreed to ride for - - - - -

sp.speaker: McGee. Anstey?
sp.p: Jones. I didn't say.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: No, but I've heard - - - -

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: You mustn't believe all you hear. Anyhow I don't expect to ride much longer.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Are you going to retire - marry, settle down, give up the track forever.

sp.speaker: [HANDWRITTEN: Jones.
sp.p: Someday.]

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Nothing of the sort. I'm a free born American, twenty-one years of age, and I can do as I please, I guess.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And who's the fair damsel?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: The sweetest girl in California.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: When did this all happen?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Two years ago.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: When you were riding in 'Frisco?

sp.speaker:
Jones. Yes.
McGee.
sp.p: Say, when did you first see her?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: You want to know everything.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Well, I'd like to know that much.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Well, it's a long story, Mack.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Well, I'll listen to it.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Would you like to hear it?

sp.speaker: McGee. I would.
sp.p: Jones. The first time I saw her, I was perched on a 50 to 1 shot that ought to have been dragging on ice wagon.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: You were sitting on the horse.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Yes, going to the post on an old nag. A girl leaned over the rail and shouted, I've got a bet on you Jonesy, so out and win.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: The girl shouted -

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: And then ran away, disappeared, but her face was photographed and my heart was the film. I can't tell you how I felt because I don't know myself.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Well, did you win?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Did I win?
Why, I just pushed that old skate's nose to the barrier and from the second the starter said go-

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yes, go on, go on -

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: You'll be betting on this race before you get through.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: By golly, you had me going that time.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Well, I'm not going to grandstand it and describe the race but on the square, Mack, I could make that scene in Old Kentucky look like thirty cents.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And when the race was over you met the girl that looked over the rail, and she's the girl you're going to marry, and everything ends happily and so on, etc.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Now you have it.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: But how about her parents?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: She has none-lives with her aunt. She's a very wealthy girl, Mack. Her father was known as the Copper King. His name was Gerald Gates.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And the Aunt's name is? --

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Kenworth. She's a fanatic on the subject of reform.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: President of the Female Reformers?

sp.speaker:
Jones. Yes.
McGee.
sp.p: Why it's like a story in a book.

sp.speaker: Jones. How is that?
sp.p: McGee. She's here.

sp.speaker:
Jones. Who?
McGee.
sp.p: Mrs. Kenworth.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Here, in London?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yes, but that's not all. She's engaged to be married.

sp.speaker: Jones. To whom?
sp.p: McGee. Anthony Anstey.

sp.speaker: Jones. The Devil.
sp.p: McGee. That's what I think he is.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Must be some mistake.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Sure, wasn't I talking with her. Didn't she tell me the whole business?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: What business?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: About the engagement with Anstey, and how he's going to introduce her to an English nobleman that they're going to cart back to America to marry the girl.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: An English Nobleman?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yes, the Earl of something, I forgot the name. Sure I met Anstey. He introduced me to her and she up and tells me the whole story.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: There's something behind this Mack.

sp.speaker: McGee. Evidently.
sp.p: Jones. Is Anstey here?

sp.speaker: McGee. Certainly.
sp.p: Jones. I'll be back in a minute.
sp.stage: (Turns to go off L. and McGee pulls him back.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Here now, Jonsey, keep cool! Don't rush head long into trouble, think it over. Keep you head, there's lots of time.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: You're right, Mack, but I've had my eye on that fellow for a long time.
sp.stage: (Both go to R. Enter Florabelle from hotel down C. followed by American girls)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Who said Johnny Jones was here?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: What Florabelle Fly?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Jonsey.
Turn around and let me see you.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: How do I look?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Just as cute a kid as ever.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: What are you doing in London?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Came to see you win the Derby.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Did you hear that, Mack?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: He'll do that all right.
sp.stage: (Girls pulling at Fly's dress, seeking introduction.)

sp.speaker: Fly
sp.p: Ladies, allow me. Mr. Johnny Jones, the American Jockey.
sp.stage: (She crosses over to McGee and Jonsey crosses to girls. They swarm around him like a lot of bees and in a second he is enclosed with them. Fly laughingly to McGee.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Pretty soft for Jonsey, eh, Mack?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Oh, when I was a boy I had a lot of women after me.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: And how was that?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I stole a pocketbook.
sp.stage: (They exit arm in arm R.1.E. laughing.)

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Well, by Jove, this is a treat. You know I didn't think there were so many Americans in the whole city of London. I suppose you're all going to the Derby?

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: You bet we are.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Want a little tip?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: You bet we do.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Pawn your jewelry, go in hock, and play Yankee Doodle straight to win.

div.stage: (American girl exits on run 1.E.R.)
MUSIC CUE. SONG: "YANKEE DOODLE BOY"
(After number all exit - both sides. Jones goes into hotel.)
MUSIC CUE.
(Enter Mrs. Kenworth and Anstey, R.1.E. arm in arm.) (Waiter comes and places table and chairs. Jones comes from hotel down to waiter.)
(Business, and follows Anstey and Mrs. Kenworth off door left.)
(Boy crosses from door R. and exits 1.E.L. Shouting)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anthony Anstey. Anthony Anstey!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Come right along old chap.
sp.stage: (Enter Henry from hotel and looks around. Runs up and motions to Goldie O.K. Enter Goldie in male attire, and goes directly to table R.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Fine day for the Derby.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Glorious indeed.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: A cigarette, Leslie.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes ma'am.

sp.speaker: Goldie. Yes ma'am.
sp.p: Henry. I beg your pardon, I mean-yes sir.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: No, no, Lordship, Lordship!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, of course, your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Now remember, I'm the Earl of Bloomsbury.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Very well, your Earlship. Is Earlship correct? What?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Lordship, just Lordship.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, just Lordship.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Yes, can't you think?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: How can I think and keep these whiskers on at the same time.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.stage: (Sees waiter, who appears and comes down to Henry.)
sp.p: Sh---- don't do that around here.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: Something wanted sir?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Just one moment, do you want anything Early?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Don't call me Early.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Don't call you Early, very clever indeed.
No, the Earl doesn't want something.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: The Earl---

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: The Earl, of course the Earl.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: The Earl of what, sir?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Why the Earl of Bloomsbury.

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: The Earl of Bloomsbury, my word!
sp.stage: (Starter crosses to Goldie and Henry to extreme left.)
sp.p: I'm pleased to meet you your Earlship.
sp.stage: (Bows and goes up stage, then turns.)
sp.p: I shall not forget your Lordship.
Long live the Earl of Bloomsbury. Hurrah for the Earl of Bloomsbury. etc., etc.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: What are you strutting around like an ostrich for?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I can't help it, Goldie, I'm nervous.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Well, don't get nervous and don't call me Goldie.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: All right your steamship.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Steamship.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, no I mean your - - - - - what kind of a ship is it?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Lordship, just Lordship.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes your Lordship. Now tell me what is the idea again?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: The idea is that I am the Earl of Bloomsbury.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Then you're going to marry yourself?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Figuratively speaking. You see Mr. Anstey has never met the Earl of Bloomsbury. I am going to introduce myself to Mr. Anstey as that distinguished personage.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: But he has word that the Earl wouldn't be here for a week.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Well the Earl suddenly changed his mind- thought it quite a lark to pop in and surprise all hands.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I see, it's an awful chance, though.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: My dear boy we take chances every time we cross the street.
Sh - - -
sp.stage: (Enter Sing Song, Mrs. Kenworth and Anstey, from door L. down stage. Sing goes to extreme L.)

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.stage: (Starter coming down from hotel to Henry.)
sp.p: Anything wanted Sir?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You see, my dear, the English Derby doesn't come under the head of an ordinary horse race. It is an event anxiously looked forward to, by all classes of people in England.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Say, I understand that ministers of the gospel attend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Really, and do you think it would be perfectly proper for me to go?

sp.speaker: Anstey. Absolutely.
sp.p: Sing. Most assuredly.
sp.stage: (Sing sits down at table, interested all the time.)
(Goldie crosses Henry and over to Anstey, and Fly comes from hotel and stays on porch sizing things up.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Beg pardon, but could you tell me where I might find a gentleman named Anthony Anstey?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Right here sir.
sp.stage: (Over to her. This brings Goldie and him C. Leaves Mrs. Kenworth and Sing L. and Henry R. Henry sits down.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Ah, indeed, that makes it very single. I am the Earl of Bloomsbury.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: The Earl?

sp.speaker: Goldie. The Earl.
sp.p: Anstey. Oh, my dear Earl this is a surprisingly great honor. But I --

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: -- my sudden appearances here overwhelms you, I understand. I thought it best not to linger. Left Berlin right after I sent you the word of my delay.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Delighted, delighted, my dear Earl. I have so much to say - so much to talk of.
My dear Annette, I have the great honor to present Sir Walter Worthington - The Earl of Bloomsbury. This lady, your Lordship, is Mrs. Kenworth, of whom I spoke in my last letter.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Ah, Mrs. Kenworth, your niece is the American heiress of whom I --

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Yes, your Lordship, I am Goldie's Aunt.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Pleased, awfully pleased.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Thing are coming my way, Sing.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Earl.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: My dear Anstey - -
sp.stage: (Mrs. Kenworth over toward Henry and looks him over, with lorgnette. Henry gets up, turns and faces Mrs. Kenworth, and quickly turns from her. She goes up stage L.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I present Sing Song, Editor of the Pekin Gazette.
sp.stage: (At this Sing gets up and bows to Goldie, and Anstey up stage and joins Mrs. Kenworth. Florabelle at this point is up stage, writing in memo, and sizing up the situation. Mrs. Kenworth strolls up stage and looks Florabelle over.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Delighted - delighted, delighted, pardon, just a moment.
sp.stage: (Goldie goes over to Henry. Mrs. Kenworth crosses down stage to extreme left, with Sing and Anstey also at same time extreme L. Leaving center clear.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: He introduced her to her Aunt as the Earl of Bloomsbury. Great Scot what a story.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Leslie, you had best go to the Kings Club, and inform them that the Prince and myself will desire the Royal billiard table at seven P.M.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: And I say, Leslie.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Cash that draft.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Which one, sir?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: The one for the sixty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, your Championship.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Beastly lot, these servants.
sp.stage: (Anstey Sing and Mrs. Kenworth now sitting at table.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Going to the Derby, your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Rather, haven't missed the Derby since my fifth year.
sp.stage: (Goldie goes up around table and down to extreme left - Fly follows.) (Wilson and McGee enter from hotel, arm in arm, followed by all the girls laughing and dress the stage.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.stage: (Wilson and McGee both down stage to Anstey.)
sp.p: Say, I just had a fight with an English bell boy. He got sore because I said cricket was a kid's game.
CUE -FIFE AND DRUMS.
sp.stage: (All this down stage and looks off R.1.E. Shouting Here comes the soldiers. At this Reformers appear on balcony- soldiers enter first E.R. and line up R.)

sp.speaker: Starter.
sp.p: What's the blooming row, now?

sp.speaker: Soldier.
sp.p: We are here to excort our Chinese visitor to the Derby.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Ah, my noble escort. One moment.
sp.stage: (Goes and calls Chinese girls from door L.)
sp.p: Ah Mila, Ah Moy, Ah Goy, Ah Vong!
I told them we were ready.

sp.speaker: Soldier.
sp.p: Attention, company, left foot forward march.
sp.stage: (Soldiers exit single file 1.E.R. Sing and Chinese girls follow. McGee and Wilson stroll over to table R. and sit down.)

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.stage: (Enters from hotel. Comes down stage C. and looks off R. after soldiers.)
sp.p: Hello, what's all the excitement?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Jonsey, just the boy I want to see.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Is this Mrs. Kenworth?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, but for Heaven's sake don't tip my hand as a sporting man.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I want to talk to you.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I haven't time now.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Well you'll make time to talk to me.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Just what I say. You're playing a crooked game Mr. Anstey, and I'm going to find out what it is.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Why, you young rat I'll - - -
sp.stage: (Attempts to strike a blow with cane, and Jones wrests it from him and breaks it.)

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: There goes your cane, Anstey, and your neck will be next if you don't stop where you are.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Why Anthony, what does this mean?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I'll tell you what it means, Mrs. Kenworth, I'm engaged to your niece, and have been ever since I left 'Frisco a year ago.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth. WHAT?
sp.p: Anstey. Do you hear this, Mrs. Kenworth? This common jockey, this rat of the stables, engaged to your niece.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: This man is mad.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: A big joke, isn't it - a jockey engaged to an heiress.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, a gigantic joke.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Is there no protection against a public insult from a madman?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Is there no protection against a woman of your sort, Mrs. Kenworth? To force upon a young girl an outrageous marriage with a cur.
sp.stage: (Jones points to Goldie and Goldie laughs.)
sp.p: who would sell himself for an American bank roll.
sp.stage: (At this Anstey steps close to Jones.)
sp.p: You just called me a rat Anstey.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: That's what you are and for this insult I'll drive you from the track, if it takes every dollar I possess.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: You'll never do that. If your record was as clean as mine, you'd have a good appetite and many a good night's rest. I never bet on a mount or rode a crooked race in all my life, and you've turned every dirty trick that's known to the racing world - fixed your jockeys - pulled your horses, and fooled the public time after time, and you call me a rat?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: That's what you are.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I wasn't too much of a rat to receive this check from you ten days ago, Anstey,
sp.stage: (At this Jones tears up check, and at finish of speech throws check in Anstey's face. Everybody horror struck.)
sp.p: But I don't want your kind of money, and there's your check, there it is, right square in your face.
sp.stage: (A scream by all. Mrs. Kenworth goes up stage and exits in door L.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I'm not through with you yet.
sp.stage: (Up stage and follows Mrs. Kenworth off.)

div.stage: - - - - CURTAIN - - - -

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: SCENE: SOUTHAMPTON DOCK, with the Steamer St. Hurrah ready to steam away.

(OPENING NUMBER - SAILORS OF THE ST. HURRAH CHORUS, sung by Sailors. At finish of chorus boy and Reformers enter R.3.E. Go around stage singing chorus. Sailors join them. At finish boy exits R.2.E. Reformers exit ship, and sailors go aboard ship and stay there. Enter Fly, an American girl and do number. At finish of their chorus, Fly and girls exit aboard ship. At finish of number enter Wilson R.2.E. precedd by boy carrying his grip.)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Right this way, sir. Here's the St. Hurrah right here, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: That's all right I'll take the grip.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Got your hand out again, have you? Tip, tip, tip. That's all I've been doing since I landed in England, but I'll give you a tip. The next time I tip anyody, I'll be tipsy.

Did you hear that one? The next time I tip anybody I'll be tipsy. All my own stuff. I made it up as it went along. Gee, whiz! You're a great audience. Prommised your mother you'd never laugh, didn't you?
There ain't going to be any donation.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Now he's what I call a nice little fellow. Great company.
sp.stage: (At this point Captain Squirvy comes down the gang plank and crosses Wilson)
sp.p: Hello whiskers.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Whiskers.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Say, how do you expect the barber shops to keep open, if you're going to let those things grow out all the time.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Is it me you address?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I don't want your address, I want you to get a shave.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Now don't get sore, Whiskers.

sp.speaker: Captain. Whiskers?
sp.p: Wilson.
Say what is this, the Fall River Line?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Bah!

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: There's another nice little fellow. Say what time does this boat break out?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Are you going to sail with me, sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Who am I?
Who am I, sir - I am ----

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Wait a minute, just tell me who you are, don't rave about it.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I am Captain Squirvy, sir.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Captain of what?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Captain of the St. Hurrah.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Gee, whiz! I thought you were Captain of the base ball team. Say, Whiskers, -

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Not Whiskers, sir, not whiskers.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Not Whiskers, well, they look like whiskers.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: My name is Squirvy, sir. SQUIRVY.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: How'd you get that name?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: That was my father's name.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Oh, well, then you're not to blame. It's hereditary. Come on let's get a drink.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Thank you, I'm not thirsty.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Well, you don't have to be thirsty, don't you ever wash your face till it gets dirty?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Very good - Very good!

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Do you like that one?

sp.speaker: Captain. Splendid.
sp.p: Wilson. Would you like to hear another?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Wilson,
sp.p: Well there ain't going to be any more.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: What are you laughing at?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Really, I don't know.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: What's the good of laughing? Save up your laughter for a good Joke. Then burst out and make a fool out of it.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Why don't you go and get a sleep?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Why don't you go and get a shave?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Bah!
sp.stage: (Walks away to R.2.E. and looks off)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: It's plain to be seen that the Captain hates himself.
sp.stage: (Train effect. Enter girls from ship and down plank.)

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Come on, girls, let's see if our baggage is all right.
sp.stage: (Girls come down plank, turn and go extreme left. Wilson stays C.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Ah, how do you do bright eyes.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.p: How do you do, sir?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Say, have you girls met the Captain?

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.p: Yes, have you seen him?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: There he is.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Ah, ladies.
sp.stage: (Girls all run over to him except the first girl, who lingers with Wilson)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Say, the Captain's a devil among the ladies, isn't he?

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: Yes, he's a fine fellow.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I'll bet he spends his money like a sailor. Always stick up for a sailor. Remember Jack Sharkey was a sailor. Well here I go on the water wagon.

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.stage: (Goes and joins girls and turns to Wilson.)
sp.p: Hope you won't be sick.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Hope I won't be sick! Well, how do you suppose the doctors are going to make a living if we don't get sick every once in a while. Gee, whiz, if you had your way you'd put all practicing physicicans out of business. You've got the meanest disposition of any woman I ever met in all my life.
sp.stage: (Girls all laugh as he exits and stroll to C.) (Captain approaching first girl goes left.)

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Tell me, who is that fellow?

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: A boat gambler I presume. I'll keep my eye on him.
sp.stage: (Both go C. At this boy comes from L.2.E. and joins Captain.)

sp.speaker: 1st Girl.
sp.p: I hope we don't have a storm at sea.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: A storm at sea to me is as welcome as the sunshine of a spring morning to a birdie in its nest. When the thunger crashes --
and the lightning flashes --
the rain pours down, the pyramid waves splash the deck - the old ship is rocking like a cradle and the --

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Ah, Captain!

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Bah, sailors, eh?

sp.speaker: 2nd Girl.
sp.p: Captain have you always been a sailor?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: No indeed, when I was a boy like this lad I worked in a store.
sp.stage: (SONG- "Captain of a Ten-Day Boat", sung by Captain and Girls, sad boys enter at introduction from ship and do number with them. At finish all exit R.2.E. Also boy and Captain stays left. Florabelle appears on deck of boat at finish of this number with kodak, and coming down plank laughing.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Captain Squirvy entertains the American girls with a sailor's hornpipe on the Southampton Dock. More news for the Searcher.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Ah, Miss Fly, going to cross?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: With you again, Captain.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Well, well, with Sing Song, the Chinese newspaper man, and Florabelle Fly, the press will be well represented on the St. Hurrah.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: A boat load of celebrities, eh, Captain?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, I suppose you know Johnny Jones crosses with us.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes, poor Jones.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: That's what I say, Fly. Why in the world was he ever ruled off the English track?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: No one seems to know.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Do you suppose it was because he lost the English Derby?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Well, of course his horse was favorite, but then other favorites have lost.
Stand up straight, fix your tie. There have been no facts made public. We only know he's off the track.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: There's something behind it all.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Evidently, but it's all a mystery up to now.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Hello, what's this?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Mrs. Kenworth and her female Reformers have arrived.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I read of them in the London Times. Sing Song is to accompany them back to San Francisco I see.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes, going to protect them from the Highbinders.
She's proved a great subject for the press.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: A better subject for an insane asylum, I should say.
sp.stage: (At this Mrs. Kenworth enters from R.2.E. preceded by boy with grips.)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here you are, here's the St. Hurrah. Right this way, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Why Mrs. Kenworth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Ah, Miss Fly, awfully glad to hear that you are going to make the trip with us.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I'm tickled to death myself. Have you met Captain Squirvy, Mrs. Kenworth -

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Mrs. Kenworth!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Captain? Captain of the St. Hurrah?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: I suppose you have crossed the ocean many times.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: A hundred and three times, madam, and twice in a row boat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Brave fellow. I like brave men.
I adore brave women who stand by their rights.
sp.stage: (At this boy comes from ship - crosses to R. bus. with trunk.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Here's one who stands by her rights alright, alright, alright.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I've heard a great deal of you Mrs. Kenworth through the newspapers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Newspapers! Rubbish.
sp.stage: (Captain crosses to C. Mrs. Kenworth to L. and looks up at boat.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I wonder if she was looking at me when she said that.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: It looks that way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Have my little dearies arrived yet, Captain?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Yes, half hour ago.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Will you be so kind as to present them to the stewardess, my dear Captain?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: With pleasure, my dear Mrs. Kenworth, and I assure you the pleasure is all mine. I will see to them at once.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Tell me, is it true the Earl of Bloomsbury is to marry your niece, Mrs. Kenworth?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Yes, indeed. Ah, lucky girl. An Earl for a husband.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Then her engagement to the American jockey Jones is ----

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: ---Jones, that insignificant, horrid creature. Whatever foolish escapade my niece may have had with this jockey was a joke, a mere lark. Goldie is fascinating, I might say coquetteish, and the poor fool took her seriously.
sp.stage: (At this sailors enter from R.2.E. and Boy exits R.2.E.)
sp.p: Ridiculous, ridiculous.
sp.stage: (Laughs haughtily and exits aboard ship. Sailors take trunks and exit aboard ship.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: The story gets stranger as the chapters progress.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Come along your lordship, right this way, your lordship.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Hello, here comes my heroine now, from England to America in male attire, and the Searcher scoops the story.
sp.stage: (Down stage as Goldie and Henry enter, turns and snaps them with her kodak. Enter Henry carrying grips, and so followed by Goldie still disguised as the Earl.)

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Here we are, your lordship, here's the St. Hurrah. Shall we go right aboard?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: May as well, I suppose.
Beastly looking boat, isn't it?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, awful looking catamoran.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Ah, Miss Fly.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Howdy, my dear Earl. I suppose you're anxious for the trip to be over with, and see what your future wife really looks like.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: I don't care what she looks like.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: He wouldn't care if she looked like thirty cents.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Has Miss Gates heard of the match?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: I believe her Aunt cabled her the good news, that I had agreed to become her husband. Ah, she's the lucky girl.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: What do you suppose the outcome will be?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: I don't care what the outcome is.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: No, by Jove it's the income he's after.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: But I understand this girl is in love with Johnny Jones, the jockey.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: If she marries him she's disinherited.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Jones don't care, he loves her for herself.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Fly. He told me so.
sp.p: Goldie.
He did, when?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Don't you think we'd best get aboard, your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Put the luggage in my stateroom, Leslie.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Don't talk too much.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I never did like these female newspaper men.
Coming right aboard your silly old boat, Captain, and you shall make way for the Earl of Bloomsbury.
sp.stage: (At this Wilson comes down plank and meets Henry, who look each other over.)
sp.p: My word, what a silly looking man.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Say, how do you expect the expressman to make a living if you are going to carry that stuff around with you all the time?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You mind your own business you old fool, and if you don't I'll give you a piece of my mind, you silly old sponge cake.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Now don't get sore Clare, he'll be great company for me, all right.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.stage: (To fly who comes down stage R.)
sp.p: And so you really think this Jones would marry Miss Gates if she hadn't a dollar in the world?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, but I hardly think she'll care for him now that he's disgracefully accused of throwing the English Derby. I understand his suspension extends to America, and that he is actually ruled off the track forever.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: She loves him just the same.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: What makes you think so?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Oh, silly fools, these girls you know.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Are you going aboard, my dear Earl?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: No, I'm going to sit here and watch the sailors bid good-bye to their sweethearts.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Jimney Christmas, what a story this is getting to be.
sp.stage: (Exits aboard ship) MUSIC CUE. (SONG - "GOOD-BYE FLO" Sung by Goldie with chorus behind her. At finish crowd hollering and shouting without. Goldie and sailors exit aboard ship, and girls exit R.2.E. Enter McGee on run from R.2.E.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: By gorra, I never got in a crowd like that in my life. They're trying to mob poor Jonsey. Swarmed around him like a lot of bees.
Go it, Jonsey, go it. He soaked one of them, down he goes. Give it to him again.
sp.stage: (Supposed to be looking at fight off R.)
sp.p: Come on, come on, and lick the devil -----
sp.stage: (Enter Jones with jeers, hisses and yelling)
sp.p: Are you all right? Turn around and let me see.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Why, I could fight my way through as an army of ours like them.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Who the devil started it?

sp.speaker: Jones. Anstey!
sp.p: McGee. Anstey.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: The minute I stepped from the train he shouted to the crowd, "there he is Johnny Jones, the crooked jockey", why they were on top of me before I where I was at.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Where is the kid that had our grips?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.stage: (To kid as he enters with grips)
sp.p: Ah, there you are! Good boy!
sp.stage: (He starts to walk plank - Jones follows, boy turns.)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Good boy nothing. If I'd have known as who you were I'd never carried your blooming luggage. Johnny Jones, eh? Threw the English Derby, did you?
I hope the next horse you get on falls down and breaks your blooming neck.
Robber, thief, cad!

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I'm a hot favorite, Mack.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: You are in bad luck, kid.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I throw the English Derby? Why I never tried so hard in all my life, yet for the last three days every kid in the streets of London has jeered me - pointed me out to passers-by with calls of thief! Robber! Cad! and all such things.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And no satisfaction from the English Club?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Not a bit. Called before the steward and suspended. Called before the committee and ruled off. No satisfaction, no explanation, except what the papers have printed and they merely intimate that I may have ridden a crooked race.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And even if you did, you're not the first that - - -

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Wait a minute, Mac. Do you think I did?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I didn't say that, Jonsey.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: No, but you may as well. Gee, whiz! Haven't I a friend in the world?
sp.stage: (McGee offers Jones his hand. Wilson, who has just come down plank.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Have you got any money?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I've got all kinds of money.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: To hell with the friends.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.stage: (Jones and McGee cross Wilson and look at him surprised and go up stage L.)
sp.p: There's no hand, kid. I'm going to go the route for you and stick right with you till you prove to the whole damn world that you are on the square.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: That's awfully nice of you, Mack.
sp.stage: (Cheers, and shouts in distance at this)

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I guess I'll get aboard before I'm mobbed again.

div.stage: (Jones, McGee and Wilson go aboard ship and stay there.)
MUSIC CUE - FORTE.

(ENTER TOMMY ATKINS SOLDIERS AND SING SONG; AND the Four Chinese Girls, who do big number and dance. At finish of dance Chinese girls exit aboard ship, and Tommy Atkins Soldiers exit R.2.E. Sing Song stays on stage - goes up to plank. McGee exits into ship. Henry comes on deck, now listening. BOTH. Sailors are on the deck all through this set.)

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.stage: (Coming down plank at finish of number.)
sp.p: Ah, my dear Sing Song, welcome to the St. Hurrah.

sp.speaker: Sing Song.
sp.p: Captain Squirvy, I believe.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: At your service.

sp.speaker: Sing Song.
sp.p: I've heard Mr. Anstey speak of you.
sp.stage: (Crosses to left and meets Mrs. Kenworth who is coming down plank. Captain crosses looks off right.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Where is Anthony?

sp.speaker: Sing Song.
sp.p: He's with the police.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: With the police.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: The Earl of Bloomsbury turned out to be a bogus Earl.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: A bogus Earl?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: So it seems. Anstey is now giving the detectives a full description of the counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: He's already aboard the ship.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Good. I believe they intend to surround the boat and capture him at once.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Will wonders never cease?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: They'll get him if he's aboard the ship.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: He's aboard the ship right now.

sp.speaker: Heny.
sp.p: But he won't be in a minute.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Oh, this is horrible, terrible.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: What seems to be the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Nothing, everything.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Come along Perkins.
