sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Ah, Anthony!

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You heard!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Yes, what does it mean?

sp.speaker: Isnpector.
sp.p: Imprisonment for life, Ma'am if we get the man.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Inspector Perkins!

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: Hello, Captain.
May I have your permission to search the St. Hurrah for a person enrolled on the passenger list as the Earl of Bloomsbury?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Go as far as you like, Inspector. Come along, I'll help you. This way, Inspector.
sp.stage: (Inspector follows to plank and stops, turns to Anstey) (By this time Sing Song has gone up stage and has joined Anstey and Mrs. Kenworth.)
(At this Wilson comes aboard ship and down plank.)

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: Have no fear Mr. Anstey, I'll take him dead or alive.
sp.stage: (Inspector starts up plank and meet Wilson who is just coming down - then stops.)
sp.p: Hello, Wilson, how are you?
sp.stage: (Holding out hand. Jones exits into ship.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: There must be some mistake.
sp.stage: (Anstey, Sing and Mrs. Kenworth stand at R.2.E. pantomine talk.)

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, I thought you were somebody else.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Well, if I ain't somebody you thought I was, I must be somebody else.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: All right, Captain, I'm coming.
sp.stage: (Exits on run. Wilson goes up stage.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: How did you discover him to be an imposter?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: This letter.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: From the real Earl?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Exactly I've wired him to follow on the next boat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: The wretch may approach my dearies. I must protect them at once.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Nothing to fear now, my dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: But the brute may speak to them.
sp.stage: (Exit hurriedly and excited into boat. Anstey goes over to boat and sees her exit.)

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Who do you suppose this masquerading person can be?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Some imposter or fool taking a desperate chance.
The Chinese Lottery papers, where are they?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: There they are.

sp.speaker:
Anstey. Oh!
Sing.
sp.p: I see Jones' name is on the passenger list.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, the little rat.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: He'll beat the Earl to the field of battle.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Will he? I'll cable Chung Fow to kidnap the girl. On Mrs. Kenworth's arrival in Frisco she will learn of the disappearance of her niece.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: What's the scheme?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Ransom money for the girl's release, and a promise of silence, and no more uprising against the Chinese Lottery game.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: It's blackmail.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Not at all. Business proposition.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Tell me, how was that jockey affair arranged?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Easily enough. On the day of the Derby I circulated a report that Jones was bought by an American syndicate to throw the race. My appearance at the track strengthened the story to such an extent that the American colony watched every move I made. I took a long chance on Jones' defeat; bet six thousand pounds on British Boy, which put the English betting ring into a wild turmoil. Long before the race was run, Jones was called before the Stewards. He must have convinced them of his innocence, for he went to the post on Yankee Doodle. Now had he finished our ot the money, under ordinary circumstances, well and good, but meeting defeat in the face of the accusation and the American Money switching over to the long shot, British Boy, brought the English to their feet with a cry of fraud. He was mobbed in the paddock, barely escaped with his life. Jones unconditionally suspended and ruled off the English track.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Hop, Toy, Sing.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: The whole scheme has to be handled with gloves, my dear Sing Song, and no one but a conniving, scheming, deep- thinking man, could have succesfully operated this little game I played, for sweet revenge. I'll not soon forget the insult he publicly hurled at me in the Court of the Hotel Cecil.
sp.stage: (Anstey laughs heartily. Wilson who has been up stage now pushes his way in between the two.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Say, will you boys join me in a little drink?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: No clinky.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I'm just as much obliged.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: You boys are great commons all right.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You'll excuse me I'll - - -

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Beg pardon --
sp.stage: (Business of brushing off his shoulder with one hand and taking papers from pocket with the other. Puts papers in his own pocket.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I thought I saw some dust on your shoulder.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You're liable to see a lot of things the way you are going.

sp.speaker: Wilson
sp.p: You won't see much where you're going.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: I wonder if they captured the counterfeit Earl.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I believe they have him by this time.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Sorry you boys won't join me. I wouldn't have your disposition for anything in the world.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.stage: (Comes down stage C. Looks up at boat.)
sp.p: Some fool or another.
sp.stage: (At this point Inspector appears on deck. Fly follows him and watches.)
sp.p: Hello, did you get your man?

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: No, he's vanished. Disappeared entirely.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: That's strange.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: He must be ashore.
sp.stage: (He descends - Fly follows and watches the Inspector.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You'd best guard the boat.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: I have men here.
sp.stage: (Whistles off R.2.E. four English policemen appear from R.2.E.)
sp.p: You have the description?

sp.speaker: Four Bobbies.
sp.p: Aye Governor.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: Go aboard and keep your eyes open.

sp.speaker: Four Bobbies.
sp.p: Thank you, Governor.

sp.speaker: Inspecotr.
sp.p: I'll look about the station.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Watch the London train.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: He'll not escape, sir.
sp.stage: (Exits R.2.E. Fly follows him off.) (When policeman exit in boat. Henry appears on deck and starts down plank.)

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.stage: (Who is left, writing in some book.)
sp.p: This will be news for the Pekin Gazette.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Come along, Sing, let's get aboard.
sp.stage: (They start for the boat and meet Henry, who has discarded his diguises and is back to himself.)

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: How do you do, Mr. Anstey.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Well, well, my young friend of the American bar, going to cross?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Expect to. Excuse me - - -

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: This way, Sing.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Good, I must see that my ladies are comfortably situated.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I'll be with you directly.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Very good, I'll be in the cabin or somewhere.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Oh, I say - - -

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Did you call, Mr. Anstey?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes.
sp.stage: (Looks about to see if the coast is clear)
sp.p: How about the little French girl, is she going to cross?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes, oh, yes. She's aboard the ship.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Good, good!
Splendid, splendid! Go right along Sing, I'm coming.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: What an old villain he is. I would like to know what game he and that Chinamen are playing. By Jove, what a narrow escape! Goldie got rid of her diguise none too soon.
sp.stage: (At this Inspector enters in great hurry from R.2.E. towards ship Fly follows, and Henry goes R.C.)
sp.p:
Hello, the Inspector.
Inspector.
sp.stage: (Turns and sees Henry who is R.C.)
sp.p: You name, sir?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Hapgood - - Henry Hapgood.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: His hiding place is on that ship. He was seen going aboard.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Your men are searching.
Hello, who is this?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You remember me, Captain, I crossed with you.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Oh, yes, Mr. - - -

sp.speaker: Henry. Hapgood.
sp.p: Captain. Hapgood. Correct.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: All right, Captain?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: All right? Yes.
sp.stage: (NOTE - At this the policemen appear on deck.)

sp.speaker: 1st Bobby.
sp.p: Not a sight of his Governor.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: Guard that deck.
sp.stage: (The police all salute and walk up and down deck.)
(NOTE - When Inspector entered from R.2.E. he was again followed by Fly who stare up stage and makes note of all his actions.)

sp.speaker: Fly
sp.p: What's all the excitement?

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: Your name, please.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Florabelle Fly, representing the San Francisco Searcher.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: The San Francisco Searcher, did you say?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Yes, you seem interested.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Well, rather, that is to say, I've -- I've -- heard of the paper.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Oh, I see.
you needn't be alarmed, Inspector, I'm perfectly harmless.
sp.stage: (Laughs heartily and runs up plank and exits aboard ship)

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I dare say you'll be glad to get home.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You bet I will, Captain.
No more masquerading trips for Henry, once I hit good old California.
sp.stage: MUSIC CUE. "GOOD OLD CALIFORNIA" (Sung by Henry and male chorus, Sailors stroll on from boat at introduction. Bobbies on plank and Captain aside of Henry. After number policemen exit ship. Enter McGee from ship calling.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Hello, what's the matter, are we all pinched?
sp.stage: (Looking at police as he descends plank.)

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.stage: (Who has been standing at foot of plank during number. Goes toward McGee.)
sp.p: Your name, please.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Where are you from?

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: Scotland Yard.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I don't want to play in your yard.

sp.speaker: Inspector
sp.p: Your name?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: McGee.
sp.stage: (Inspector nods - turns and goes up stage.)

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Hello, Mack.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Ship ahoy, Captain, what's the fuss?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: All kinds of excitement.
sp.stage: (Enter Goldie down plank at this and stops short as she meets Inspector.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Pardon, Monsieur, have you seen a Mr. Hapgood?

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: Hapgood? Yes.
sp.stage: (Henry who has since song been looking off up stage R.3.E. comes over himself to greet Goldie.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Thank you.
It's all up, I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: What's happened?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: I met my aunt face to face.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: She knew you?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: I'm afraid so. She stopped and stared and - - - -

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Sh- - -
sp.stage: (Goldie and Henry walk to entrance L.) (At this Mrs. Kenworth and Anstey on deck and come down plank, followed by Fly who stays up stage R.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You must be mistkane, my dear. It can't be possible that-----

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: But I tell you I'm not mistaken. I know the girl when I see her, I - -
Look, see, there she is.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Did you call me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.stage: (Looks from one to the other in surprise.)
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: My dear, allow me! Miss Fanchette. Mlle. I present Mrs. Kenworth.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: I am very pleased to make my acquaintance, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: What is the name?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: My name? Fanchette, Rosario Fanchette.
sp.stage: (Mrs. Kenworth stands and stares at Goldie.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: She thought this French girl was her niece.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Her niece?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Is there something I can do for you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: No, nothing.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: I'll see you again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: What a remarkable resemblence.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.stage: (Still amused. Crosses to her as she speaks. Laughingly)
sp.p: Well, my dear, are you satisfied?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Who is this girl?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: A Parisian flirt - nothing more nor less.
You see, my dear, how easily one may be mistaken.
sp.stage: (Turns back again to Goldie and Henry.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: If I were not sure Goldie is at school in San Francisco, I'd swear she - - -

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Ah, Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.stage: (Captain at this point turns and goes up stage and joins Fly.)
(NOTE: Florabelle has been on stage making notes all during this scene, she having followed on stage Mrs. Kenworth and Anstey.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Hello, going to cross Mr. McGee?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I'm going as far as the boat goes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Good, I'm awfully glad.
sp.stage: (Takes his arm and they stroll right)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: And she thought I was her niece.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: That's it.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: She must be crazy.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You see, my dear ---
sp.stage: (Sees her with McGee R. stands looking at them)
sp.p: With McGee again.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Goldie you're a wonder!

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Another narrow escape.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: And you thought she was your niece?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: I could have sworn it.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Oh, my dear, --
sp.stage: (McGee and Mrs. Kenworth take no notice of him)
sp.p: My darling --- my honeysuckle --
sp.stage: (They laugh heartily and talk in pantomine)
sp.p: Damn that Irishman.
sp.stage: (Inspector who has been on deck comes down plank and down stage to Anstey.)

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: I can't account for our man's disappearance.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Nor I. I'll take a look about the boat myself.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: Keep a sharp watch. I'll see if my men in the station have an inkling.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: She seems very much interested in McGee.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.stage: (Meets Wilson who enters R.2.E. and as Wilson crosses him he turns and looks at him.)
sp.p: I'd like to know what he's doing in England.
sp.stage: (Wilson directly over to plank and exits into boat. At this point Fly and Captain come down C.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: And the Earl turns out to be an imposter, very strange. Isn't it?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Yes, very.
sp.stage: (Effect of train arriving without. At this Tommy Atkins boy enters R.2.E. and exit into ship. Leaves Fly and goes up stage, looking off R.2.E.)
sp.p: Hello, here's another train.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Mrs. Kenworth converses with Timothy McGee on the subject of reform.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: That's just what I think.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Say, you're raising the devil.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: And raising my salary at the same time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Why I never saw such a thing.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: You mean me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: It's positively striking, I ----

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Oh, yes, the gentleman told me I look like a young lady ----

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: What do you say to a stroll on deck, Mrs. Kenworth?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Delighted.
sp.stage: (At this crowd hollering and jeering without.)

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: Something up.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: It sounds like a riot.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: I'll have to see what all this about.
sp.stage: (Exits on run R.2.E. Noise subsides and Henry and Goldie stroll to L. Down stage and Jones comes down from ship.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Hello, Jonsey, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: There he is.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Keep your nerve.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: There's a poker game aboard, Mack.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: A poker game?
What's the limit?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: You're the limit.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Politics and poker are two games where a man should always have a few things up his sleeve.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.stage: (Walking directly to Jones, and Goldie going R. and looks off.)
sp.p: Hello, Jones.

sp.speaker: Jones. How are you?
sp.p: Henry. You kno't know me, my name's Hapgood. I've been a great follower of yours. Sorry to hear of your trouble.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Forget it, my boy. It doesn't bother me in the least. Who's the little swell?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, pardon me, Mlle.
This gentleman is the great Johnny Jones, the American jockey.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Thanks, old chap.
sp.stage: (Both cross Henry to L. Jones to Goldie.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Ah, the great Johnny Jones. Delighted to meet you.
What is the matter? Why you look at me so?
I am a nice girl, eh?
sp.stage: (Jones walks right up to her and looks into her face.)
(Henry down stage at this extreme left) (Goldie runs over to Henry)
sp.p: What is the matter with him. Is he crazy?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: What seems to be the trouble, Jones?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Who is this girl?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Fanchette. Rosario Fanchette.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Certainly, I've met her a dozen times in Paris. She's a --- Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Nothing.
sp.stage: (Boy dashes from R.2.E. and on to boat calling.)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Henry Hapgood. Message for Henry Hapgood.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That's me.
Here boy, here you are- that's me.
sp.stage: (Exits on run up plank and aboard ship.)
(Jones over to Goldie - stares at her again. At this Fly enters R.2.E. and over to plank. Looks down and sees Jones and Goldie. Stays on plank and watches.)

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Oh, again I look like someone, eh? Just now the lady tells me I look like her niece and - - -

sp.speaker: Jones
sp.p: The lady told you this?

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Yes, she was all excited. She thought I look so much like --

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: She means Mrs. Kenworth.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Who I look like now, eh?
I say, who I look like now, eh?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p:
Why, you look just like a girl I know.
MUSIC CUE.
sp.stage: (SONG AND DANCE done by Jones and Goldie. At finish of number Goldie exits R.2.E. Jones looking after her. Fly comes down plank.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Ah, that's the time I caught you, Jonsey. Naughty, naughty.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Say, who is she?

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: How should I know. Pretty isn't she?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I should say so, by Jove!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: You haven't fallen in love, have you?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Not exactly that, but - - -

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: She looks like the real thing, eh?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I should say she does.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Strange this Earl should turn out to be an imposter.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Yes, very strange.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: He doesn't suspect - good.
sp.stage: (At this point Captain and Anstey come down plank all excited.)

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Where could you have lost them?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I can't imagine Captain. They were in my pocket not ten minutes ago.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Absolutely sure. I tell you, Captain, I've been robbed.

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Something lost?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Valuable papers.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Yes, very valuable papers. It's the work of a thief.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I don't know who the thief can be.
sp.stage: (At this point Jones down stage to Anstey and stops.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.stage: (Turns - sees Jones and looks at him.)
sp.p: I think I do. A man who will cheat the public will pick a pocket.
sp.stage: (At this point Mrs. Kenworth enters from ship)

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Look out for your watch, Captain.
sp.stage: (Turns and goes up to side of plank. Bus. of Captain throwing up hands - turns and goes up stage.)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Anstey loses valuable papers.
sp.stage: (Anstey turns up stage - sees Mrs. Kenworth on plank.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Ah, my dear.
The papers.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: It's nothing. Papers of importance in a business way, that's all.
sp.stage: (Mrs. Kenworth crosses over to Fly L. At this the four Bobbies appear on plank.)

sp.speaker: 1st Bobby.
sp.p: Is the Inspector about, Governor?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: No, what luck?

sp.speaker: 1st Bobby.
sp.p: None. Our man is not aboard this ship.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: I'm glad of that.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Then, where the devil is he?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Strange!

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Very.
sp.stage: (Noises of crowd yelling and jeering without.)

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: 1st Bobby.
sp.p: That's for us.
sp.stage: (Four bobbies exit on a run from ship to R.2.E.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: What's up now?
sp.stage: (At this point Wilson appears on plank. Sailor enters at this R.2.E.)

sp.speaker: Sailor.
sp.stage: (Excited, salutes Captain, takes Captain by the hand and goes down stage C.)
sp.p: Captain, big crowd, police driving back. They want to get the ship to mob Johnny Jones.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Mob Johnny Jones?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I can see my finale.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Come my dear, we'd best get aboard.
sp.stage: (Captain, Fly and Mrs. Jenworth exit aboard ship)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.stage: (Down to Jones, and slips him a pistol.)
sp.p: Here use this if it comes to a show down.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: What's all the fuss?
sp.stage: (Everything excitement around stage and jeering of crowd is heard without. Mob scene here. Mob enter with police trying to fight them back. At this Wilson and Jones shoot off pistol. Mob who get frightened, turn and run off R.2.E. lots of noise.)
(As mob exits Tommy Atkins boy enter from aboard ship, down stage.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Do you know what you are doing? Do you know all England has been cheated, robbed by this our you are trying to protect? Who are you?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I'm a Democrat.
sp.stage: (Anstey exits hurriedly into ship. Wilson down stage C. calling.)
sp.p: Come here, everybody.
sp.stage: (All surround him. Inspector at his right. Jones and Hapgood at L.)
sp.p: This man Anstey is scheming to drive Johnny Jones out of England.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: But he'll not do it. I'll stick here and prove that I'm on the level.

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: That's the boy, Jonsey.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I'll have a written confession of his scheme before the ship is two hours out.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: What's the inducement?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.stage: (Takes papers from pocket and shows them)
sp.p: These papers.

sp.speaker: Inspector.
sp.p: I'll report to headquarters. You signal Lizard Island.

sp.speaker: Wilson. How?
sp.p: Inspector. By a skyrocket from the ship.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Good! A skyrocket from the ship at Lizard Island will prove that Johnny Jones is on the square.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: If that rocket goes off I'll be on the next boat.

sp.speaker: Sailors.
sp.p: All ashore that's going Ashore!

div.stage: MUSIC CUE.

(Bobbies and Tommy Atkins Boy line up R. Wilson goes aboard ship. Goldie who exited R.2.E. now enters same and goes aboard ship. Hapgood stays on plank during number, which Jones sings. All action up stage. Henry down and business with Jones. Then leaves Jones and exits aboard ship. Boy comes down from ship and gives Jones his hat and grip, and exits aboard ship. Sailor brings Jones' trunk and dog from ship, and takes them off R.2.E. and returns to ship. Everybody sing as ship strikes out, and bell rings, dark stage. TRANSFORMATION. Piano Chorus.)
-- CURTAIN --

div.head: ACT III
div.stage: (Business at opening - Chinaman crossing stage - also policeman.)
(Enter Wilson up stage - R.3.E. and meets policeman L.C.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Say, excuse me. Could you tell me where I can find a policeman?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Are you speaking to me?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Certainly I'm speaking to you. How do you suppose people are going to get acquainted if they don't speak to each other.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Move on, move on.
sp.stage: (Crosses him -goes up to R.U.E. and looks off.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Gee, you've got a mean disposition.
sp.stage: (Shouting and yelling heard without and back of stage.)
sp.p: Who's making the holler?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: The Chinamen are celebrating the arrival of Sing Song.

sp.speaker: Wilson. Who is he?
sp.p: Officer. A Chinese newspaper man, sent here by the Emperor to study modern Journalism.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Gee, I thought it was Grover Cleveland's birthday.
Come on, let's get a drink.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: I don't drink on duty.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Well then drink on me.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Are you looking for somebody?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Yes, I want to find a policeman.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.p: Well, what do I look like?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I'm ashamed to tell you.
sp.stage: (Drum beating without and officer exits up stage R.U.E. and swinging club)
(As policemen exits, newsboys enter R.1.E. with papers and runs around stage calling.)

sp.speaker: Newsboy.
sp.p: Extra, extra, full account of the great kidnapping case. Extra - all about the disappearance of Goldie Gates. Extra- extra.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.stage: (Looks about, and whistles up to balcony left.)
(Chinamen appears on balcony and leans over to see who it is.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Are you Chung Fow?

sp.speaker: Chinamen.
sp.p: Yes, all right.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Tell Anstey I'm here.

sp.speaker: Chinaman. Wilson?
sp.p: Wilson. Yes, Wilson.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: This is a nice, cheerful little place. If I lived in 'Frisco I'd hang out here all the time.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.stage: (Enters from down left, slaps door behind him and looks all about until he sees Wilson, R.C.)
sp.p: Is that you?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: No. --This is me, -- that's you there.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Well, I'm here, I kept my word.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Yes, for the first time in your life.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Here. Put it down, put it down. Don't force me to chastize you. Be a nice good little boy and listen to me.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Go on, don't waste words - you know my disposition.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Yes, you've got a damn mean disposition.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: You've got me cornered Wilson, but don't torture me, please don't torture me!

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I'm not going to. However a few words will not be amiss. To begin with, Mr. Anstey, the lottery King -

I've been after you since you first began to deal that crooked game in the Chinese quarter. Any time you crossed the Pacific or the Atlantic I was within shooting distance. It took me three years to lend you and now you make one wrong move, or refuse to write or do anything I dictate, and I'll send you up for the rest of your natural existance.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: And if I turn state's evidence -

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: You're a free man, pretty soft, eh?
sp.stage: (Wilson laughs at him as he grits his teeth.)

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Laugh. Ruin a man, then laugh at his disgrace.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Why didn't you think of that when you tried to put that little jockey out of business in England?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Well, that's all past and gone. Hasn't be been reinstated? Hasn't my written confession ruled me off the track forever? I'm a ruined man, - what more do you want?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I want that kidnapped girl before I leave Chinatown.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: The Chinamen know nothing of her disappearance.

sp.speaker: Wilson
sp.p: You cabled Chung Fow to kidnap the girl.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: But the girl was not in Frisco.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Anstey if you lie to me, I'll make you break stones twelve hours a day for the next twenty years.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: Well, I'll submit to the inevitable, anything you say, but don't send me away, please don't.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Go in there and wait for me, and don't forget the job in the stone yard I spoke about.
Go on - Twenty-three.

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.stage: (Exits into den and slams the door after him.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: He's what I call a nice little fellow.
It's about time McGee kept his appointment. He's fifteen minutes late.
sp.stage: (Shouts and yells heard without at this.)
(Wilson goes L. Enter McGee and Mrs. Kenworth R.U.E.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: It's all right now, cheer up. The whole town is on the search.
Wilson was to be here at eleven, and -----

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: It's a quarter past eleven now.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Hello.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Tell me, is there any news?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Now don't get excited. Everything will turn out all right. She's in safe keeping even if she is kidnapped.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Of course, sure they're only waiting for the ransom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: I'll pay anything. Promise silence, but --

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: The best thing you can do is to keep quiet. I'll find the girl before the night is over.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Do, and I'll reward you.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I don't want any reward, I want to talk to you.
sp.stage: (At this McGee goes upstage and looks off right.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I am tickled to death to see you with this man - McGee.
sp.stage: (At mention of his name McGee turns and swells up.)
sp.p: He's a good man - I know him. He's a Brooklyn Elk. You don't want to overlook this jockey Jones. They may have fixed that horse in England but they couldn't fix the jockey. He's the candy all right. I don't blame your niece for getting sweet on him.
but this man with the gray looks. He's no good, arouse mit him. I'm going to get him to sign this, the skedew. I want to give you a little bit of advice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Yes, yes, go on.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Give up this band of reformers and let the Chinamen alone. Don't dictate to anyone whom they should marry. Stay at home, do your knitting and sewing and let the rest of the world take care of itself.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Why sir, I ---

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Now don't mind me; that was on my chest and I had to get it off - That's all.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Where's Jones?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Jones is doing a little detective work on his own hook.
sp.stage: (Drums beating without again and big noise. All up stage look off R.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Sing Song's reception in Chinatown.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Now go take a walk and come back in about ten minutes, and if I haven't got your niece by that time it's because she's not in Frisco.
sp.stage: (Mrs. Kenworth and McGee start to exit)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: How can I ever thank you?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Send me an invitation to the wedding.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: We'll do that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Oh, I forget ----

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Why Mr. McGee, I'm surprised, I -----

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Slip of the tongue--slip of the tongue.
sp.stage: (They exit arm in arm laughing L.1.E.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.stage: (Over to den R. and nears in.)
sp.p: I wonder how Jones is getting on with his detective work.
sp.stage: (Chinaman appears - Enter from L.U.E. to C. and whistles to Wilson.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Good, I've been waiting for you - what's new?

sp.speaker: Chinaman.
sp.p: Anstey's right - the girl never was kidnapped.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: I never thought she was.

sp.speaker: Chinaman.
sp.p: Sing Song's now reviewing Chinatown.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Go in there and tell Anstey to put his signature to this.
Tell him to grab a fast train east. He won't have a Chinaman's chance in Frisco from the minute he signs it.
sp.stage: (Chinaman goes over to den L. raps on door and when the slit is raised says "Ho la ha." Door opens and he exits into den L.)
(Wilson goes to extreme R.1.E. takes out watch and looks.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Quarter past eleven. Quarter past eleven. Gee I'm glad I'm not in Boston.
sp.stage: (Enter Chinaman R.U.E. down stage and exit into den L. Enter Hapgood from R.U.E. and looks all around followed by Goldie, who is veiled.)

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: She's disappeared but I'm almost certain she came this way.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Was she alone?

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: Oh, no, McGee was with her. He's been running in and out of the Pinkerton offices all day. The whole town's on a search for you, Goldie. It ceases to be a joke.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: What'll I do?

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: Give up this deception. Let people know who you are. Things are getting serious.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Things are just as I want them. I've at least taught my Aunt a lesson, and that's what I started out to do.

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: I know, but the notoriety.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: Notoriety. She started all that with her crusading society.

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: But think of Jones. That poor kid has turned Frisco upside down in search of you.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: And at the same time convinced my Aunt what a man he is.

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: Great Scott, she's agreed to your marriage, done away with her society; offered all sorts of rewards for your restoration. I can't see the sense of carrying things further.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: But just imagine the fun I'm having, reading the accounts of my disappearance. The kidnapping stories, the search of Chinatown and so on.....

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: I don't see anything to laugh at, Goldie. It's a nightmare with me.
sp.stage: (Both run up stage and look off R.)
(NOTE- As drums beat Wilson enters from 1.E.R. sees Goldie and Hapgood and watches both under cover. Hapgood and Goldie run up stage and look off R.)

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.stage: (Down stage C. at R. of guide.)
sp.p: Here comes the Chinese parade - let's get away from here.
sp.stage: (They exit hurriedly L.1.E. MUSIC CUE. MARCH.)
(At finish of march the Chinese are left on stage, and Sing Song enters with guide from R.U.E.)

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.stage: (Down stage C. at R. of guide.)
sp.p: Wonderful sight--wonderful sight! One would think China had been transplanted in America. The Emperor would be proud to behold this settlement-- proud of his people.

sp.speaker: Guide.
sp.p: This is the famous Chinese gambling den of Frisco.

sp.speaker: Sing. Gambling den?
sp.p: Guide. The Chinese lottery game has made it famous.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: A disgrace to our people.

sp.speaker: Guide.
sp.p: It's controlled by Americans, I believe.

sp.speaker: Sing. Oh, I see.
sp.p: Guide. It's one of the greatest sights of Chinatown - shall we visit here?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Not in there - not I. We will proceed to the Joss house. Lead on my good people.
sp.stage: (MUSIC CUE- Parade marches off, leaving Sing Song and Guide alone.)

sp.speaker: Guide.
sp.p: This way, Sing.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Wait, perhaps 'twould be best were I to visit here. The Emperor should know of his workings. Come, I will see this place.
sp.stage: (Both go to den L. and guide raps.)

sp.speaker: Chinaman.
sp.p: Ho, la, ma.

sp.speaker: Guide.
sp.p: This way.
sp.stage: (Sing exits and Guide follows. A lot of Chinese talk from Sing as they exit.)
(At same time Florabelle enters from den R.H. side.)

sp.speaker: Florabelle.
sp.p: Sing Song visits lottery den- Johnny Jones turns detective. Now Miss Gates if you'll please become yourself again I'll have a sensational finish to a story that will make every newspaper in America sit up and notice things.
sp.stage: (At this Chinaman opens slot at door of den L. Hollers.)

sp.speaker: Chinamen.
sp.p: Sing Ta!
sp.stage: (Fly sees door of den open - runs up stage R. and looks. All attention. Enter Chinamen from den and blows whistle - looks off R. Enter Wilson R.1.E. and run up to Guide. Guide pantomines to him that Sing is in there and he exits den L. followed by Chinaman.)

sp.speaker: Florabelle.
sp.p: A dash of mystery about all this. I'll keep my eyes open here.
sp.stage: (Exits L.2.E.) (Newsboys rush on stage again, and around and exits R.U.E.)

sp.speaker: Newsboys.
sp.p: Extra - extra - full account of the kidnapping case. Extra - extra!

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: There isn't a nook or corner in Chinatown I haven't searched, and what a study it all is. By golly, life's a funny proposition after all.
sp.stage: (Sits on box down stage L. and sings a song.)

(After song Chinaman appears on balcony of den L. and blows whistle. Enter policeman from upper R.E. and Wilson from den L. and meets policman, and points to den L. police enter den L. Wilson goes up stage. Jones gets up from box and looks into door of den R. Enter Hapgood and Goldie up stage L.)

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: Why, there is Jones.

sp.speaker: Goldie.
sp.p: The poor kid. Go on, tell him, I'll wait in the cab.
sp.stage: (Goldie turns and faces Wilson who motions her to keep quiet and takes her off R.U.E.)

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: By George!
Oh, I say, Jones?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.stage: (Jones turns, sees who it is and grasps his hand.)

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: Miss Gates is waiting for you.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Miss Gates, where?

sp.speaker: Hapgood. At home.
sp.p: Jones. What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: Keep cool, she has a lot to say, and wants to see you right away.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: Hapgood
sp.p: Well, rather, I - - - (Jones gets excited) now don't get excited, here's your Aunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: This suspense is very trying.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Everything will be all right, you leave it to Wilson.
Hello, Jones, any news?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: All kinds of news, Mrs. Kenworth - - - -

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.stage: (Pulls Jones back and Crosses to Mrs. Kenworth.)
sp.p: Wait a minute let me tell it. Mrs. Kenworth, there's a young lady in the cab wants to see you right away.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: A young lady?

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: Yes, Mlle. Fanchette, you'll perhaps remember having crosses the ocean with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.p: Fanchette?

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: The French girl.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: I always thought so, by Jove.

sp.speaker: Hapgood.
sp.p: Permit me Mrs. Kenworth.
sp.stage: (Offers her his arm which she accepts.)
sp.p: You'll excuse me Mr. McGee, I'll be with you in a minute, Jonsey.
sp.stage: (They exit arm in arm hurriedly R.U.E.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: What'sit all about?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: Nothing, everything - it's all right. I understand it all now.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Yes, but I don't.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: No, but you shall. How can I ever thank you for sticking by me like you did.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Just win a few races for me this summer.

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: If I ever ride again
that's the answer.
sp.stage: (Anstey enters from den L. crosses to R. Jones and McGee see him come out.)
sp.p: Helo, Anstey, where are you going?

sp.speaker: Anstey.
sp.p: I'm going as far away from here as I can get. I don't stand a Chinaman's chance in this burg.

sp.speaker: McGee. Poor devil?
sp.p: Jones. It's the only chance he had.

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: I'll keep my eye on that Larry-Buck, and see that he grabs a fast train for the East.
sp.stage: (Jones runs up and looks after them)

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Hello, Jonsey, any news?

sp.speaker: Jones.
sp.p: All kinds of news - Goldie Gates and Mlle. Franchette ---

sp.speaker: Fly.
sp.p: Are one and the same.
sp.stage: (Lots of life all through this till finish. Enter Wilson and Goldie, followed by McGee and Mrs. Kenworth from R.1.E. all excitment.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.stage: (Has Goldie by the hand. Sees Jones and goes up to him.)
sp.p: There he is now.
sp.stage: (Goldie crosses Wilson to Jones, who embraces her. Enter Mrs. Kewnorth preceded by McGee.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Come on, now. Everything will be all right.
Why, there's Wilson now.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Yes, and there's your niece.
sp.stage: (Pulls Goldie from Jones and over to Mrs. Kenworth. Both embrace.)

sp.speaker: McGee.
sp.p: Well, how can we reward you?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.stage: (Takes Goldie from Mrs. Kenworth and pulls her over to Jones)
sp.p: There's the only reward I want.
sp.stage: (At this a lot of noise heard inside of den. Enter police from den with Sing handcuffed. At this Mrs. Kenworth takes Goldie away from Jones and both exit excitedly on run L.1.E. and Fly exits R.U.E.)

sp.speaker: Sergeant.
sp.p: Come on, get a move on, we'll be a long time together.
sp.stage: (Sing crosses officer. Other policemen go up stage R. and line up. Wilson comes down stage to Sing.)

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: What does this all mean?

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: It means that you and me are going to take a long trip to China together -- Do you play Pinocle?

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Ling, Kow, Fring to long, China tok ki Ling ki la and so on.
sp.stage: (Denouncing Wilson. McGee and Wilson go extreme left and look on.)

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Now don't lose your head, you'll lose that soon enough. I'm going to introduce you to the Emperor all over again.
sp.stage: (Bus. with hand indicating "You'll lose your head" and turns to go.)

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.p: Gee, you've got a mean disposition.

sp.speaker: Wilson.
sp.p: Come on.
sp.stage: (Starts to exit R.1.E. and turns in time to see Sing turn to strike officer)
sp.p: Here! Come on - be careful.

div.stage: (Wilson, Sing and Officer exit L.E.R. McGee leaves Jones and follows them off on run.)

(Lights up - chorus enter singing. Mrs. Kenworth, Goldie and McGee enter 1.E.R. McGee stays L. Mrs. Kenworth takes Goldie over to Jones, and they embrace. Mrs. Kenworth goes back to McGee. Hapgood and Fly enter R.U.E. and down stage center arm in arm singing.)
-- CURTAIN --
